results.title: The Bat and the rainbow
results.creator_credit: Educational Media Australia, David Corke, Ken J. Widdowson and Australian National University
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Aboriginal legends”.
The Bat’s wife was stolen from him by Rainbow. To get her back Bat mortally wounds the sleeping Rainbow. Bleeding badly, Rainbow rolls into the waterhole where he can still be found. Occasionally, during wet weather, Rainbow rises from the waterhole and stretches his handsome body across the sky. This title is also available in a compilation with two other legends under the title “Aboriginal legends. No. 3” Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.

results.title: Why the emu cannot fly
results.creator_credit: David Corke, Ken J. Widdowson, Educational Media Australia and Australian National University
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Aboriginal legends”.
This film is illustrated by drawings of an Aboriginal legend from the book “Djugurba: tales from the Spirit Time” and tells how the emu’s vanity about his beautiful wings brings about his downfall.

results.title: Inganarr the giant serpent
results.creator_credit: David Corke, Ken J. Widdowson, Educational Media Australia and Australian National University
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Aboriginal legends”.
A serpent with an enormous appetite, Inganarr, ate all the people of North Goulburn Island and then proceeded to eat the people of Arnhem Land. Fortunately Inganarr suffered from indigestion due to his gluttony and the tribespeople poured out of his mouth in droves. This helps to explain why there are people in eastern Arnhem Land but no people in western Arnhem Land. This film is also available as a compilation film entitled Aboriginal legends no. 3. Suitable for middle and upper primary level.

results.title: Franklin: wild river
results.creator_credit: Michael Cordell, Chris Noone, Stacey Gavrily and Wombat Films
results.brief_description: Documentary which looks at the controversy over the proposed damming of the Franklin and Gordon Rivers in South West Tasmania and argues for the conservation of this wilderness area. Provides a brief history of the region and follows a three week journey down the Franklin River with Dr. Bob Brown, a conservationist who has intimate knowledge of the river.

results.title: Kangaroos. Part 1. Biography
results.creator_credit: Ian Walker, John Shaw, David Bairstow and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian Wildlife”.
Part one begins with the evolution of the kangaroo, tracing its development into over 50 species, from tree-dwellers to the better-known “big red”. The feeding, and mating habits of various species are examined, also birth and development in the pouch are studied. Narrated by Lionel Long.

results.title: Careers in building
results.creator_credit: Bruce McNaughton, Ronald Mason and Academy Film Productions
results.brief_description: A vocational guidance film on the building industry. Shows the erection of a tall city office block; the men and women of the building industry at work in their diverse activities; the craftsmanship and skill required to erect a typical Australian brick veneer home; the development of a new airline terminal; and the construction work involved in a guided missile rocket pad.

results.title: Japanese Story
results.creator_credit: Jill Bilcock, Alison Tilson, Sue Brooks, Sue Maslin, Film Victoria, ScreenWest, Showtime Australia, Film Finance Corporation Australia and Gecko Films
results.brief_description:
Australian geologist Sandy (Toni Collette) lands the unwanted task of showing a Japanese businessman Hiromitsu (Gotaro Tsunashima) around the mines and deserts of the Pilbara, hoping to sell his company the geology software she has been co-developing. Hiromitsu mistakes her for his driver and demands they go off-road, unaware of the dangers. The two journey further into the West Australian desert, gradually leaving what they know about each other and themselves behind.

Winner of 21 Australian film awards including 8 AFI Awards. Cast also includes Matthew Dyktynski, Lynette Curran, Yumiko Tanaka, John Howard.

results.title: The Dish [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Jill Bilcock, Rob Sitch, Jane Kennedy, Tom Gleisner, Santo Cilauro, Robert Hirsch and Working Dog
results.brief_description: Based on a true story, ‘The Dish’ tells the story of the first landing on the moon and the role a bunch of technicians in remote Australia played in delivering those images to the world. In stark contrast to images we’ve seen before in films and the news of NASA control rooms - hundreds of experts working around the clock to ensure a successful mission - the film segues to the activities of staff in the sleepy remote town of Parkes, South Australia, where the equal task of tracking the lunar module was shared with NASA. After we witness the Australian’s low-key approach to this responsibility what is revealed in this gentle comedy is a cultural critique; a celebration of the unique qualities that make us Australian and defines our cultural values.
